case_name: Albert Moses and K. L. Dhawan v. State

facts.text: Criminal Appeal Nos. 196 and 197 of 1960 filed.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal Nos. 196 and 197 of 60. Appeal by special leave- from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated May 1958 of Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in Criminal Appeals Nos. 3-D and 1-T of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave- from the judgment and order dated May 1958, of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in, Criminal Appeals Nos. 3-D and I -T  of 1958.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on February 15, 1962 by KAPUR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. February 15. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-These two appeals

facts.text: Appellants convicted under sections 120B and 420 Indian Penal Code and section 5(1)d read with section 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act.

anchor.surface_text: confirming the companyviction of the appellants under ss.120 B and 420 Indian Penal Code, and s.5 1    d  read with s. 5 2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1917 And sentencing each

facts.text: Each appellant sentenced to aggregate of six months rigorous imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1917 And sentencing each of them to an aggregate sentence of six months rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: Albert Moses was the Principal incharge of the Rehabilitation Centre, Malviya Nagar and Kalkaji under the Ministry of Rehabilitation.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Albert Mossses was the Principal incharge of the Rehabilitation Centre, Malviya Nagar and Kalkaji under the Ministry of Rehabilitation.

facts.text: K. L. Dhawan was a partner in the firm M/s. Dhawan Co.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, K. L. Dhawan, was a partner in the firm named M s. Dhawan Co.

facts.text: M/s. Dhawan Co. supplied a surface plate for Rs. 1,950/- to the Works Centre.

anchor.surface_text: and they supplied a surface plate for a sum of Rs. 1,950/- to the Works Centre of which the appellant Albert Moses was the Principal.

facts.text: Albert Moses was Principal of the Works Centre.

anchor.surface_text: to the Works Centre of which the appellant Albert Moses was the Principal.

facts.text: Trial of appellants and R. P. Dhawan commenced on May 21, 1956 in Court of Mr. Jawala Das, Special Judge, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The trial of the appellants and R. P. Dhawan, who has been acquitted, companymenced in the Court of Mr. Jawala Das, Special Judge, Delhi, and he heard the case from the date of the institution of the proceedings on May, 21, 1956

facts.text: Mr. Jawala Das heard the case till October 26, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: to October 26, 1956. He heard the prosecution evidence which was closed on October 26, 1956.

facts.text: Prosecution evidence closed on October 26, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: He heard the prosecution evidence which was closed on October 26, 1956.

facts.text: Mr. P. D. Sharma, Special Judge, Delhi took up the case from December 20, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The case was then taken up by Mr. P. D. Sharma, Special Judge, Delhi, from December 20, 1956.

facts.text: Mr. P. D. Sharma examined defence witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: He examined defence witnesses and finally companyvicted the appellants

facts.text: Mr. P. D. Sharma convicted the appellants and acquitted R. P. Dhawan.

anchor.surface_text: and finally companyvicted the appellants of the offences already mentioned and acquitted R. P. Dhawan.

facts.text: Appeal taken to Punjab High Court against conviction and sentence.

anchor.surface_text: Against the companyviction and sentence an appeal was taken to the High Court

facts.text: Punjab High Court upheld the conviction and sentence.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the respondent relies on sub.s.  3  of S. 8 of the Criminal Law Amendment Act  Act 46 of 1952  which makes the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure, in so far as they are number inconsistent with that Act, applicable to proceedings before a Special Judge and also provides that a Special Judge shall be deemed to be a Court of Session when trying a case under the Criminal Law Amendment Act  46 of 1952 .

concepts.interpretation: makes provisions of CrPC applicable insofar as not inconsistent with the Act; Special Judge deemed Court of Session
